name: A2A
summary: Well-designed enterprise coordination protocol. Agent Cards enable discovery without central registries. But 50+ corporate partners and Google's backing create a gravitational pull that may become hard to resist — the protocol could become the 'enterprise default' before alternatives mature.

feedbackLoop.note: Task lifecycle states (submitted → working → completed) provide clear visibility.

edgeCases.note: Broad scope. Tries to handle discovery, delegation, streaming, security — many edge cases.

ambiguity.note: Agent Cards lack cryptographic signatures — impersonation possible. Success/failure can be ambiguous in multi-hop delegation.

redundancy.note: Significant overlap with ACP, ANP, and AITP. Multiple protocols solving similar problems.

nesting.note: Multi-agent delegation can create recursive task chains that are hard to trace.

exitCost.note: 50+ enterprise partners building on A2A. Switching costs compound with each integration.

identityPenetration.note: Enterprise teams increasingly frame agent architecture in A2A terms. 'Agent Card thinking' is becoming an identity.

agencyPreservation.note: Agents define their own capabilities. No central authority dictates behavior.

controlInvisibility.note: Google's influence is visible now but may become invisible as A2A becomes 'just how agents talk.'

crisisMindset.note: Some FOMO-driven adoption — 'everyone else is on A2A.' Enterprise herd behavior.
